cwe_description: The product uses a resource that has not been initialized. This can lead to unpredictable behavior, crashes, or information disclosure.
explanation: The code attempts to set IP header fields (protocol, saddr, daddr) using ip_hdr(skb) before calling skb_reserve. The skb_reserve function then moves skb->data forward, effectively making the previously written header fields part of the reserved, unused space. Consequently, when the skb is later passed to routing functions like ip_route_input_rcu or ip_route_output_key_hash_rcu, the IP header fields they read from skb->data will be uninitialized, leading to incorrect routing decisions, potential denial of service, or security policy bypass.

cwe_description: The program uses a variable that has not been initialized. This can lead to unpredictable behavior, including crashes, incorrect calculations, or information disclosure.
explanation: The code incorrectly prepares an sk_buff for routing. IP header fields (protocol, saddr, daddr) are written to the beginning of the buffer using ip_hdr(skb) after skb_reset_network_header. Subsequently, skb_reserve(skb, MAX_HEADER + sizeof(struct iphdr)) is called, which increments skb->network_header by the reserved length. This effectively moves the network header pointer past the previously written IP header data. Consequently, when routing functions like ip_route_input_rcu or ip_route_output_key_hash_rcu later access the IP header using ip_hdr(skb), they will read from an uninitialized memory region at the new, incorrect skb->network_header offset. This leads to the use of uninitialized data for critical routing decisions, potentially causing denial of service, information leaks, or other unpredictable kernel behavior.
